description: Bernoulli focus-throughput: scope constriction → velocity increase
hypothesis: Narrow focus (few domains) → higher L+P throughput per session (Bernoulli: constriction → speed↑)
verdict: PROXY_PARADOX: r=+0.317 (OPPOSITE to Bernoulli prediction — more domains → MORE L+P in this proxy)
paradox_explanation: The 'domains mentioned in session notes' proxy is confounded with session size/activity. Highly productive sessions naturally mention more domains because they DO more — not because breadth causes productivity. This is a measurement selection artifact.
reframing: Bernoulli applies at a FINER granularity than session-level domain count. The correct analogy: within a session, scope narrowing (fewer open tasks, tighter focus window) increases per-task throughput. F-EVO1 r=-0.835 used scope cluster count over S184-S189, a tighter signal.

bernoulli_evidence_from_f_evo1.verdict: SUPPORTED at finer scale with correct proxy

implication: Bernoulli is supported by F-EVO1 (r=-0.835) at scope-cluster level, not refuted. The F-FLD3 counter-signal reveals that domain breadth is a SIZE proxy, not a FOCUS proxy. Need within-session scope tightness metric.
next: F-FLD3 OPEN; needs within-session scope cluster metric, not cross-session domain mentions
